headline.main: Liggett Pact: Harbinger Of Legal Battles to Come

docs.abstract: State attorneys general from around nation celebrate Liggett Group's agreement to label its cigarettes as addictive, to release internal industry documents and to allow its executives to testify in future lawsuits; lawyers representing other tobacco companies have begun effort to prevent documents--crown jewel of settlement--from ever seeing light of day (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: As the Liggett Group Inc. resolved one set of lawsuits, it set the stage for a new and thorny round of litigation that will keep tobacco companies and plaintiffs' lawyers battling among themselves for months, if not years. Yesterday, state attorneys general from around the nation celebrated Liggett's agreement to label its cigarettes as addictive, to release internal industry documents and to allow its executives to testify in future lawsuits. The attorneys general said the company's agreement gave them new weapons in the legal war involving the tobacco industry.

headline.main: CIGARETTE MAKER CONCEDES SMOKING CAN CAUSE CANCER

docs.abstract: Liggett Group, in extraordinary admission, acknowledges that tobacco is addictive and causes cancer, and says tobacco companies have for decades consciously marketed their products to children; these concessions by company, smallest of country's five leading cigarette makers, are central provisions in its agreement to settle lawsuits filed by 22 states that accuse industry of hiding knowledge of adverse health effects of tobacco; plaintiffs seek compensation from industry for billions of dollars in Medicaid costs incurred by states in paying for treatment of people with smoking-related ailments; Vice Pres Al Gore calls settlement 'historic victory for the American people'; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: In an extraordinary admission, one of the nation's major cigarette makers acknowledged today that tobacco is addictive and causes cancer, and said tobacco companies had for decades consciously marketed their products to children as young as 14. Those concessions by the company, the Liggett Group Inc., the smallest of the country's five leading cigarette makers, are central provisions in its agreement, announced today, to settle lawsuits filed by 22 states that accuse the industry of hiding knowledge of the adverse health effects of tobacco. The plaintiffs, including New York and New Jersey, seek compensation from the industry for billions of dollars in annual Medicaid costs incurred by the states in paying for treatment of people with smoking-related ailments.

headline.main: Study Plays Down the Importance of a Sleep Disorder

docs.abstract: British researchers challenge view of American doctors that high blood pressure, heart disease and strokes can be caused by sleep apnea, common disorder in which breathing is interrupted repeatedly during sleep (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: At a time when American doctors are becoming increasingly convinced that high blood pressure, heart disease and strokes can be caused by sleep apnea, a common disorder in which breathing is interrupted repeatedly during sleep, British researchers have challenged that view. They say the importance of the condition has been exaggerated. American sleep researchers have, in turn, criticized the British findings and defended the growing trend in this country to diagnose and treat the disorder aggressively, a trend that has led to an explosive growth in the number of accredited sleep clinics, to 337 now from 92 in 1987.

headline.main: Companies Could Be Plagued By Scrutiny and Regulations

docs.abstract: Liggett Group's latest move to duck out of tobacco companies' fight with 22 states has further unsettled already edgy investors and could pose fresh public relations and regulatory headaches for tobacco industry (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: The Liggett Group Inc.'s latest move to duck out of the tobacco companies' fight with 22 states has further unsettled already edgy investors and could pose fresh public relations and regulatory headaches for the tobacco industry. How serious the headaches are will largely depend on how much Liggett's moves undermine its competitors' ability to protect documents in court cases. But Liggett's willingness to agree publicly with critics about tobacco's health hazards and addictive power might also influence public opinion and Government policies in ways that could hurt its former allies.
